narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: It would be very helpful if the class went into the field for practical application of sampling techniques.

This course has much potential to be informative and useful for many students. However the focus and format this year spent much too long on explaining relatively simple concepts without much focus on sampling methods and application.This course should not spend several weeks on simple random sampling nor a majority of each class period explain the formula associated with each method. An introductory stats course should be a prerequisite allowing this course to spend more time actually teaching sampling methodologies and their applications. Instead of its theoretic focus, this course should be problem based and focus on the relative advantages and disadvantages of the different sampling methods under different circumstances.
Perhaps devote part of the class in sampling in areas other than natural resources to see how the techniques can be applied in those areas.

I would suggest that the readings and the style of teaching could be improved, especially when considered together. The in-class instruction seemed to be targeted towards students who already knew what was going on in class. Most of the people I spoke to over the course of the semester to get extra help from said they also never know what's going on in class. Perhaps starting off the semester with slightly slower instruction, breakdown of the variables, the goals, the methods, and repetition of that during the semester would be helpful. Even recurring themes, like the Horwitz-Thompson estimator, I still feel unclear about. It would have been nice to get a clearly laid out explanation of what that is, what it does, why it's important, and how it was derived. Along those lines, it would have been nice to start lectures out with a big-picture explanation of what's going on before drilling into the details. That helps students with my learning style. Also, it might be nice to get summary pages with the important statistical equations for each type of methodology and whether each one is biased, if it's precise, if it's helped by pairing with auxiliary variables, etc. For one, that would help me keep it straight; secondly, it would help me follow along in class because I would know what to look for in the lecture that explains why; and thirdly, it would help me keep my memory sharp after the class about what we learned.Given all that, I felt that the textbook didn't clarify the questions I had from class. It seemed jumbled and sometimes gave the information I needed for a certain methodology and sometimes it didn't. or it wasn't clear if it did. It would be nice to have the lectures be clear about those things I listed, so that the book may be a good supplemental resource.
We could have benefited more from field demonstrations.

Would have been good to include a brief discussion of some of the more mundane, yet practical and necessary details about actually putting these ideas into practice. Although we got a solid grounding in the theoretical underpinnings of these sampling methodologies, I do not necessarily feel prepared to put them into practice at the moment.
Teaching style. There is a strong need to make the material more accessible to the lay person.
See above.
TA support for homework. Would have loved for several review sessions to be offered leading up to the midterm and/or several example questions reviewed in classes leading up to the midterm.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Statistics are essential for many fields of research and management, and so this course was an excellent foundation for future coursework and employment by teaching methodology that I have not been exposed to before.
As a research degree student, it is essential I understand how to set up my research methodology for successful statistical interpretation, especially with only one summer to complete the research.
This course is very helpful in helping students with their field research to sample data effectively and accurately.
I'm an MF.

As mentioned, I think this class should be required for all MFS degree students. I hope to employ the sampling methods learned in this class conducting research during a career in forestry research. While I'm glad that I took Reuning-Scherer's introductory statistics class and it provided an important foundation to allow me to better understand the material in this class, I wish I had been able to take both (not concurrently) in my first year. As such, I'd recommend considering moving this class to spring semester so that students can take both Reuning-Schere and Gregoire's classes before conducting their summer research.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain knowledge and a foundation in sampling and in statistical tests, for the purpose of applying these methodologies in research and in management.
Sampling is an integral part of field research and the course came highly recommended by previous students and professors.
My adviser recommended it.
I understood that it is a very important topic for me, and I'd heard from second-year research degree students that they wish they'd taken it their first, rather than second, years.
To help me do field sampling.
I thought it would be applicable but realized by the time it was too late to drop that it really isn't.
To help me evaluate the data I gathered over the summer for my research proejct and to post-evaluate the sampling methodology I used last summer.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Reread the recommended readings several times, as the wording can be dense for those unfamiliar with mathematical notation.

If you know stats this course is a waste of time. The new sampling methods presented in the course I could have learned just as well by spending a few hours with the text.If the course continues to not have a stats prerequisite, then this would be a fine course to introduce you to some statistical considerations in sampling and various sampling methods. Especially if you have no background in stats or sampling.
Ask questions, try to keep track separately of the important equations so that you can try to understand what's going on in the course lectures.
Do the assignments well and seek for help when you need it. Do not procrastinate or else before you know it it will be finals.
Only take this course if you are SURE that you need these concepts for your future academic growth!

Work on the homework assignments with asmall group of students, rather than serving as a crutch I think you'll find that the group allows you to discuss the material, ask questions of your peers, and develop a better sense of the material.Reading the textbook does help!Meet with Professor Gregoire to ask questions, particularly on your final project. Don't be intimidated.Make sure that next fall Stand Dynamics and this course do not overlap.
